Integrating Bioenergy Production into Forest Management Objectives
Integrating Bioenergy Production into
Forest Management Objectives

• Does bioenergy production assist another
• Does bioenergy production assist another

objective such as stand improvement for high- value log production? – Note: bioenergy production may help meet non-timber goals such as fire protection, amenity values or wildlife enhancement.
objective such as stand improvement for high-
value log production?

goals such as fire protection, amenity values or wildlife
enhancement.

Timber Harvesting Residues

• During a harvesting
• During a harvesting

operation, often 25 to 45% of the tree’s biomass is left on site as residues.
operation, often 25 to 45%
of the tree’s biomass is left
on site as residues.

• About 65% of total logging
• About 65% of total logging

residues can easily be recovered for use as bioenergy
residues can easily be

bioenergy

Timber Harvesting Residues
Timber Harvesting Residues

• Easier when using even-aged silvicultural prescriptions, for example clearcutting. – Whole tree vs. log harvesting followed by residue collection – Transpiration drying
• Easier when using even-aged silvicultural
prescriptions, for example clearcutting.
– Whole tree vs. log harvesting followed by residue collection
– Transpiration drying

• May be less feasible and profitable with uneven-aged silvicultural systems, for example single-tree selection. – Group selection is an intermediate option
• May be less feasible and profitable with uneven-aged
silvicultural systems, for example single-tree selection.
– Group selection is an intermediate option

Potential Disadvantages of Residue Removal

• Biological diversity
• Biological diversity

– Can be affected by management
– Can be affected by management

• Erosion and sedimentation
• Erosion and sedimentation

– Site specific; minimize through planning etc
– Site specific; minimize through planning etc

• Damage to advanced regeneration
• Damage to advanced regeneration

Conclusions • Like other forms of forest management, biomass
Conclusions
• Like other forms of forest management, biomass

production systems can have positive and negative ecological impacts on soils, water and biodiversity
production systems can have positive and negative
ecological impacts on soils, water and biodiversity

• Mitigating negative impacts is important to producing
• Mitigating negative impacts is important to producing

energy that is truly renewable and sustainable
energy that is truly renewable and sustainable

• Low-impact operations can be designed through careful planning, practice and technology choice

careful planning, practice and technology choice
